subtitle: We have just released Issue 4 of the New Thinking Allowed magazine.
Download it for free at newthinkingallowed.org.
New Thinking Allowed is a non-profit endeavor.
Your contributions to the New Thinking Allowed
Foundation make a meaningful difference in
our ability to produce new videos.
Conversations on the Leading Edge of Knowledge
and Discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove, and I'm with Leanne Whitney. Together,
the two of us are going to introduce this video with Peter Russell called,
Cultivating Peace. Welcome, Leanne. Thank you, Jeff. Lovely to be with you again.
It's a pleasure to be with you. I should let
our viewers know right away that last July we
released an interview that you made of me in
2005 titled, Evolution of Consciousness. In fact,
for viewers who might be interested, I'm going
to link to it in the upper right-hand corner of
your screen for those who can get that link.
This video with Peter Russell is part of the same
series made in 2005. Why don't we talk a little
bit about who you were back then and why you
made these interviews? That's right, Jeff. It's
almost 20 years ago, who I was back then. I was
actually working in the film industry,
documentary films. I had completed my first film,
and these interviews with you and Peter and
others that we'll continue to release here on
New Thinking Allowed were all part of a second
documentary that I was making around the evolution
of human consciousness. At the time, I think
I tentatively titled it, Thirsting for God,
and I wanted to interview people like yourself and
Peter, researchers in the field of consciousness
studies in expanding human awareness, how to
optimize human potential, where we might be going
as a species. Yeah, so it was yourself, Peter
Russell, Gary Zukav, Russell Targ, and you all
contributed different ideas and themes. And here
in this one with Peter Russell, absolutely the
idea that consciousness is fundamental. Peter's
a longtime TM practitioner, as you know, and he,
physicist and atheist, I believe, but moved from
the scientific realm to dialogue about actually
the merging of science and spirituality and what
that would mean for us as a species, to not have
them compete but to have them actually work in
an interconnected way. And again, that was at the
heart of what also I was trying to communicate
through the film, so I thought Peter was a perfect
voice for that. Well, we'll be releasing over
the next couple of weeks the third and fourth
interviews in this series with Russell Targ and Gary Zukav. This interview with Peter,
incidentally, takes place on the waterfront in
Sausalito, California, on a boat, Peter's boat,
I gather. Yes, that's exactly. I met Peter in his
home like I had come to meet you in Las Vegas.
That's what I did with each of the interviews. I
traveled to everybody's home, and I like that. I
like to be able to see you in your own habitat,
actually, and be able to have these dialogues,
human to human, because yes, it's about the
scholarship, undoubtedly. But why I also selected
all you four is it's the idea of also embodying.
It's knowledge we have to become. It's really,
and I really feel that you, Peter, Gary, and
Russell all represented that in a really strong,
each in your own unique way, but a collective
body of knowledge that had to do with, yes,
the wisdom traditions, yes, book knowledge, but an
embodied sense of both science and spirituality,
if you will, and deep inner knowing. I noticed
during all three of the interviews we're about
to release, it was very emotional for you to
address these topics. You were going through
something in your own life at the time. I guess
maybe the best word for it would be an awakening.
Absolutely right. Back in 2000, which I believe
I've mentioned on other interviews here on the
channel, I had what's known as a pure consciousness
event. I was in a yoga room at the time, but
I wasn't actually sitting in a meditation pose.
I grabbed my mat. I was walking out of the room,
and in the fraction of a second, I knew that
consciousness is all there is and that knowledge
is structured in it. So from 2000 to 2003, I'd been
working on other projects, and then I started to
build this project that these interviews all come
from, and psychic abilities, the intuitive self,
authentic power. Those were all themes that I was
looking to explore in the movie. I like to think
about emotion as energy in motion. So for me at
that time, to have had that deep personal experience
and then to be reaching out to other scholars,
people working in the field who had been working
in the field for a while. Again, like yourself,
Peter, Gary, it was a lot of emotion and energy
that was moving through me in order to create that
project. And it's worth letting our audience know
that although you never completed this documentary,
you did go on to enter a doctoral degree program,
and you completed that and published your book on Pata√±jali and Jung,
about which we've done, I think, three previous interviews on this channel.
Yes, yes, absolutely. So I was making a movie about the evolution of consciousness.
There was something about the third act that just
wasn't gelling for me, and instead of trying to
force it, I was swept at 4.30 one morning. I woke up and was guided to google Pacifica
Graduate Institute in the middle of a dream state,
which would be perfect for anyone studying Carl
Jung. And I went on to get a PhD in Jungian
oriented depth psychology, which of course is
depth psychology in its own way, is consciousness
studies. So there's definitely an overarching
picture here, and it feels really fulfilling
to me now almost 20 years later to be releasing
these videos of timeless wisdom. I'm delighted to
have you here with me on New Thinking Allowed. I
hope that you'll join us as a guest host and be
on the channel frequently, as a matter of fact.
I would love that, Jeff, really. I love to
explore consciousness, to explore the frontiers
of knowledge, and I would love to continue interviewing and being part of the channel.
So thank you so much for that offer. And now let's watch you interview
Peter Russell on the waterfront in Sausalito, California in 2005.
So this is the basic
conflict I think that I've come to in my own journey or my own quest,
which actually makes me very emotional to talk about it because I really feel
in general as humans, we're all seeking very
few things, which would be love and peace.
But yet, I feel like we're at this time in history
where I can't even turn on the television or pick
up a newspaper without seeing so much violence
or almost the opposite end of that extreme,
just very fear-based. I just feel like I'm living in a very fear-based society.
I'm trying to reconcile those two things.
And so I know yourself, obviously, as a seeker
in all the different work that you've done,
my biggest question is, where are we? Are we
evolving as a species? Where are we going?
I'm looking for those answers because I'm so
conflicted with them myself to try to reconcile
it because it doesn't feel good. The whole idea of the love and peace feels great,
but yet that's not what I see in my external world.
I think you really hit upon the essence of the whole crisis we're in. I think firstly,
what you're saying is true. What we're all looking for is peace, love, to be at ease,
satisfaction. But what's interesting, what we're looking for is something inner.
Basically, we're looking for a more satisfying
state of consciousness. We're looking to feel
better. And that's true of absolutely everything.
I think it's true of every creature. No one wants
to suffer. No one wants to be in pain. That's true
for all of us. Where the conflict comes from is
the way we set about finding that. And we live in
a culture that tells us, if you're not at peace,
if you're not feeling at ease inside, go and
do something. Go and buy something. Go and get
a new experience. So we become focused on the
outside world. And so we're competing out there,
looking for the things we think are going to make us happy. And they don't. Well,
they do for a short bit. You go and buy yourself
a new jacket, or you have a great gourmet meal,
or you feel great temporarily. And then the
next day or week later, it's worn off and you're
looking for something else. And so we're continually taking from the environment,
trying to find this inner peace. And this is
where I think all the spiritual traditions
come in. Because what they've seen in one way or
another is like, hang on, what you're looking for
is not out there. It's inside us. And so to really
be at peace, we need to look at what is it in
ourselves that stops us being at peace, which is
really how do we create discontent for ourselves?
I believe the mind, what I call the natural mind, is actually a peaceful state of mind.
But we continually make ourselves uncomfortable
because we think, oh, I'm missing something. I
can't be happy. I don't have enough money. I don't
have the right friends. I need to be in a new
house. I need a new job, whatever it is. So it's
all of that that breeds this discontent. And then
we start going out there trying to take it. And
it leads to firstly, a lot of conflict between
people who are all trying to take, oh, you've
got what I want. And so we're fighting for it.
It leads to a lot of that. It leads to a lot of
what I call just the insane busyness of life.
We're just doing, doing, doing, never taking time
to stop. We're getting more and more stressed.
Particularly in this culture, we get more frenetic. How much can I do in a day?
Is this something the more I do, the more peace I'm going to feel?
This, I think, is the sad joke about human beings. We're so busy doing. We never get a
chance to stop and actually be at ease. And we're
so busy worrying about whether we're going to be
happy tomorrow or five years time. We never
actually stop to be happy in the present moment.
Yeah. And it's that whole thing, you know, America, where we are, you know, founded on
that pursuit of happiness. So you pursue it, but do you ever stop to be it?
Exactly. And I think, yeah, and this is because
we're pursuing it in the wrong way. We're looking
outwardly for it. I think the pursuit of happiness
is absolutely fine. And it's natural. And that's
what we should be doing. But what we should
really be questioning is, are we going about
finding it the right way? I'll tell you a very
interesting statistic. They started doing studies
back in 1957 on how many people in America felt
they were happy with what they had in life.
And back in 1957, 30% of the U.S. population
felt happy with what they had. And they'd be
doing these studies regularly over time. And now, what is it, 35, 40 years later,
the number of, you know, whatever it is, the
number of cars per household has gone up,
the number of square foot we live in, the number
of TV channels, the foods are available in
supermarkets, all of this stuff. We didn't even
have computers then. All this stuff that's meant
to improve the quality of life has expanded
enormously. You do the studies, the number of
people happy with what they have is exactly the
same, 30%. None of this has actually made us any
happier. It's made maybe life a bit more comfortable, but it's also made us busier.
Look at computers now. How many of us, how much time do we spend each week
on our computers, uselessly trying to sort out
bits of new software, doing this loading stuff,
getting rid of viruses, whatever it is. Back in the old days, when we just sort of
wrote letters, it was a lot simpler. So our life is being taken over by this.
By the complexity, yeah. So basically, is that
the crisis, I guess, that I feel? I mean, I don't
know, you know, it's like, it seems like all of
these things are meant to be very positive. I mean,
and certainly the web, the worldwide web, it
connects us all around the world instantaneously,
which is a beautiful thing. So you can look at some
of these evolutionary things that are happening,
especially in the technology world. You know,
they're great. They're serving us in a lot of ways.
But yet, it's almost like, I feel humanity in general is so desensitized.
And again, it goes back to that whole thing about love. At the end of the day,
we're loving beings, I think. I mean, that's what
I feel. Actually, it's what I feel in my gut.
But at the same time, all this technology and
different things, I think, desensitize us.
When I read about the ancient cultures, I almost
have a longing to wish that I was alive at that
time, like maybe the time of the Native Americans
before America was even founded. Because it just
seems more peaceful. I mean, I don't know that
to be true, but... Who knows? I mean, it had its
advantages. It probably had much more time to be
peaceful. And yet, it was probably a lot harder
life. You're out in the fields, maybe tending your
food, whatever it was, or whatever the weather.
We have things pretty easy and comfortable. I
think what we need to do is take the choice back
to have more time for ourselves. And what's easy is
to be sucked into it by the computers, the email,
or the television. We have to learn to say,
no, what do we want? I think with computers,
imagine books have suddenly been created and
you've found a library. You don't have to spend
your whole life sitting in the library reading
all this stuff. We have to pick and choose. And
I think it's about getting our priorities right
and saying, yes, we need to use these tools for
certain things. But also, a priority should be, I
think, for everybody is taking time for ourselves.
And actually exploring ourselves and finding that
state of ease within ourselves and realizing it
isn't going to come just from continually chasing
after fame or fashion or friends or whatever it is
we think is really good. Well, friends are
important. Let's not dismiss that. But chasing
after the things we think are going to make
us happy. Right. Because within the scheme of
friends, I suppose you find that love, you find
that meaning. Yeah. Friendship is really important.
What I meant there is people chasing after
thinking, if I just get to know this person,
that's going to make me okay. Because what we end
up doing is using people, just like we use objects.
We use our cars, we use our computers, and we
start using people. Is this person going to help
me get on? That's the side I'm referring to. Not
true friendship. Is this person going to help me
get on in life? Or is this person standing in the
way of what I want? When we get into that thinking,
then we're not treating people as other human
beings. We're just treating them as objects.
Right. The whole social climate aspect to viewing
people. Yeah. So where do you think we are as
humanity? I mean, is this where we're meant to be?
Do you feel like? I think we're at an incredibly
significant point in our evolution. Probably the
most important, most challenging, most dangerous,
and yet the one with the greatest opportunities
ever. I think you take the bigger picture.
There's two things that I think distinguishes
us from other animals. That's made us different,
particularly from the great apes and heiress
cousins. The first is that we can speak to each
other. We have verbal language. Most creatures
have some form of language, but we can actually
sit here and talk, and I can take my ideas, my
experiences, my feelings. I can encode it in words.
You can listen. We can share ideas, and through
mediums like television, we can share them with
a wide audience. So through language, we've become
a collective learning species, and the internet is
just the latest bit of technology. We are one
single mind almost learning together. And that's
given us a couple of things, given us the ability
to really understand the world. You could say the
whole of our science is a collective learning
about the world. And then the second thing that
makes us different is the fact that we have these
wonderful, flexible, manipulative organs, the human
hand, the human thumb, the fact that I can actually
touch with my fingers. A chimp can do that,
but it can't rotate its thumb around and do
that, which makes this a wonderful manipulative
organ. And so we started manipulating the world.
We started making clay pots. We started making
clothes, doing all this stuff. You combine that
with an understanding of the world. You start
creating technologies that manipulate the world
more effectively for you. And so you start getting
a culture which is something creative, and then we
start changing the world. Everything we've done,
we've basically taken the earth in various forms,
whether they're created with plastic or stone or
wood, whatever it is, and we're remolding the
planet to our own ends. And that's where this
belief system's got stuck in. We think, ah, the
more I can remold the planet, the more I can create,
the more I can do, the better things are going to
be. And that's also, I think, created a sense of
self-centeredness, sort of an egocentricity about human beings, where we get focused on
me and what can I do. And so because of that,
we've lost sight of what is really useful for
the planet. So the crisis we've reached is we've
had this incredible burst of creativity over the
last few thousand years, but particularly the
last couple of hundred years, or even the last few
decades, which is now threatening our continued
existence here. We continue taking from the planet,
using up the resources, throwing out our rubbish,
polluting the planet. It's clear we're not going
to be here much longer. The planet won't be
habitable by humans. I don't think we're going
to kill the planet, but I think it's probably
going to be, well, at least we're going to destroy
our civilization. There may be pockets of humanity
there, but it's getting pretty serious. So it's a
real wake-up call, and it's saying, great language,
technology, it's taken us out of just being
animals. It's given us this extra thing, it's expanded our consciousness,
and we have to move on from there. It's that our
awareness has to catch up with the technology
and the power we have. And I think that's the
essence of the crisis, that we have this incredible
ability to manipulate, change the world, to do
things, and yet our consciousness is still stuck
back in almost stone age consciousness. We're
still thinking, what do I need for my own person
survival? Yeah, yeah. I mean, and this is the part that makes me very emotional and
unable to understand, because what you're describing, I mean, we're destroying the
mother. We're destroying what has given birth to
us. And again, as humanity, how can we not look
around and see that? How close down are we?
Actually, like we were talking about earlier,
just even getting on an airplane today, great
technology, amazing. But to walk into that airport
and to see what you have to go through just to
get on an airplane, because of the lack of trust
between human beings, again, it's gut-wrenching
for me. So I guess one of my biggest questions
is, what do we have to do? How do we wake up? I
think there's two levels. The first is being aware
of the situation that we're talking about now.
And I think the good thing there is more and more
people are. Just what's happened the last 20 years
with the environmental lobby, people realizing
the long-term consequences. Not all governments
may be following the advice of environmentalists,
but it's becoming more and more mainstream. We're
in a process of awakening to the seriousness of
the situation and realizing it comes back to us as human beings. And that ultimately,
the way through is by changing our values, by
waking up. How do we do that is then the next
question. And for me, I think that's what all the
great spiritual traditions have been working on.
And I think all the great traditions have come from
people, individuals who have one way or another
to let go of this holding onto things and got in
touch with their own inner essence and found that
right there inside us is the ease, the peace,
the love, the fulfillment that we're looking for.
And they then started teaching people various
techniques, practices to do that. And I think
that's the most important thing is how do we help
people rediscover that level of consciousness,
which I think is there underneath all of us.
It's not something we have to create. Waking up
is not about, I'm going to become in life. I'm
going to find this different state of consciousness.
I've got to create something. It's more undoing
what we're doing. I think the natural state of
consciousness is a state of ease. We're in touch
with our hearts. I think animals are there. You
watch a dog. The dog's got nothing to do. It
doesn't start getting bored walking around and
complaining. It'll just lie there and look up and
watch you. It's in a natural state. Occasionally,
it will get upset or lose that peace. But I
think it's with the natural state. This is what
many spiritual teachers have seen is this state
of ease. And then we start worrying about whether
we've got the right things or not. We start
moving into fear. I think most fear is about,
am I going to be happy tomorrow? What's someone
going to say? What's going to happen here?
I think fear is useful when we really meet danger.
But most of the time we have fear when there's no
real danger. And all of that clouds our thinking.
And we get caught up in our stories and our worries
and what's happening. And we never touch this
other level of consciousness which is there.
And that's why most spiritual traditions have some
technique of meditation, some form of spiritual
practice, which is about calming down, even
shutting off this verbal thinking. And when you
do that, when you cut off the verbal thinking, and
it's like, ah, god, this is, yes, I remember now.
This is how it is. There's this state of ease.
This is my natural state. But I think a lot of
people go through their whole lives hardly ever
touching it. Right. But, and now as a scientist,
you obviously may be able to talk a little bit
more about this, but we have two sides to our
brain. We have a right hemisphere and a left
hemisphere. And the right, I believe, is the
feminine side and the left is the masculine side.
And the left is all rational brain thinking.
So is it possible that we've almost shut down our
right hemisphere a lot through the evolution? Like
a lot of it's about thinking. Like we think so
much. We've lost the ability to feel almost. I
don't think, I don't think it's to do with
the left and right sides of the brain because,
well, I think that that's a metaphor for what's
happening. Because both sides of the brain are
active. When you look at the brain, both sides
are active. It hasn't been shut down one side.
And the more we're learning about the brain, it's
like all parts of the brain seem to be involved
in everything. But I think as a metaphor, it's
like we've got too connected with this thinking
mode. And because of that, because we're caught in
the thinking, we lose the feeling. And particularly
in a culture which is very male dominated, and
it's that achievement, success, doing side,
working things out. The more feminine side,
the feeling side, has been, it hasn't really
been developed and it's atrophied, particularly
in the men. And so I think that's definitely a
part of it. Definitely a part of it. But it all
comes back to the same thing that we're over,
we overthink. Thinking is a very useful thing,
but we don't need to do it the whole time.
If I look at my thoughts, I reckon 95% of
my thoughts are going to be a waste of time.
Really. You know, I'm sort of thinking about what
am I going to do later? Let me think about that
when I get there. Or what happened yesterday?
Or what's someone else going to think of me?
All this stuff, I mean, I'm driving down the road.
I don't need to be thinking while I'm driving.
I need to be watching the road. But my mind
is often often distracted about this while I'm
passing a building and that sets me off thinking about somebody I used to know.
It goes on and on. The other day I was driving and I suddenly noticed,
you know, I checked my speed and it said, you
know, I was doing 60. It was 65 on the freeway.
I thought, this is perfect. We're doing perfect
speed. And I was in a very peaceful state of
consciousness before I did this. And the next
thing I remembered, I remembered how it was when
I was a kid, when my father would do 60. We'd urge
him on. Then I was thinking of the car we had and
where we used to live. And five minutes later, I'd
been off on a whole train of completely useless
thought. If I'd been just present, I'd have
probably been driving more safely. I'd have been
much more aware of the road. I'd probably been
feeling much better. Because that's the other
thing. When we get lost in a train of thought, we
lose touch with ourselves. We lose touch with the
present. And we generally create tension for
ourselves. So I think the skill is learning how
to switch off thinking when we don't need it or
lower its intensity when we don't need it. That,
I think, is the key skill we need to learn. Right.
But obviously, you know, humans were created
with the brain capacity to think like that, again, as opposed to dogs or other species.
So do you think it's an evolutionary arc where
we maybe hit the peak of what we should be doing
with the thinking aspect? Yeah, I think it's
like with anything, it's learning how to use it
constructively. And we've got, we overuse
it. So it's, yeah, we've hit that peak where
we need to think. It's wonderful to thinking,
reasoning, planning, examining our experience,
reflecting on what's happening, learning. All of
that is great. And we need to reclaim the other
aspect of our consciousness, which we've lost
sight of, which is the feeling, the being present,
the loving, being in touch with our own inner
essence, all of that. We need to reclaim that
as well. So it's like we've gone overboard
with the thinking, and it's now time to say,
okay, great, hold that. Now let's bring the other
aspect of our consciousness that we've lost,
bring that back in so that we have the two
together. Right. And then we can move from one
to the other. We need to think when thinking is
appropriate, and then we need to sit back and be
and feel and be in touch with ourselves when
that's appropriate. Yeah. And do you think that
thinking mechanism has to do with the fear and
aggression-based sort of external accumulation
of power, really, is what it is at the end of the day? It's like trying to find power,
and instead of finding inner power, it's external
power. Yeah, it is. I mean, how much of our
thinking is taken up by planning? Most people,
if you look at it, probably 50% of it is planning
style, planning what you're going to do, what
you're going to say. And it's all about how can
we be more in control of things, control of other
people, all kinds of activist belief systems,
only I can just get things right, get my life
right, get other people to be the right way,
say the right things for me, whatever it is, I'll
be happy. And we're so busy in this worrying,
planning mode, we're never taking the chance
to actually be happy in the present. That's the
irony. We're so busy thinking about the future,
we never actually enjoy the present moment.
Yeah, and again, it just makes me so emotional when you say this, because
I think if we trusted as a species, that we're
really so much more than we currently think we
are, if we really, instead of trying to find the
supernatural, or a belief in God, and I almost hate
to use that word, because it comes with so much
baggage, but let's just say a belief in the divine
presence, if we organically trusted that, instead of continually searching for it,
we'd be alive in the womb, so to speak, we would
be able to surrender, we wouldn't have to control,
because we know we're part of a dance, a divine dance, so to speak. But again,
then this really comes back to everything that
we're saying, the rational brain, the rational
mind, because of science, you can't empirically prove the supernatural,
so to speak, I don't think. I don't think so either, and I don't think we need to,
and what I find fascinating is I think all the stuff we're talking about,
I spend a lot of time talking about this stuff
in corporations, where if I mentioned anything
about the supernatural or even spiritual, people
would run a mile. What we're talking about is very
practical stuff that doesn't need to involve the
supernatural. I mean, not to say the supernatural
isn't there, but if we're just talking about
how can we make better use of our lives,
and how can we, I think we all know that we
think too much, we get caught up in this world,
and that we need to relate to each other in different ways, we all know that.
So I think it's a question of just how can you
help people do that, and I think the good news is
there's more and more people recognizing this is
the case. I mean, if you just look at the growth
of interest in things like yoga, meditation,
spiritual development, personal development
that's been going on the last 10, 20 years, it's
phenomenal. So people are changing, people are
looking. And I think that's one of the things,
you know, I'm not a dog or another kind of animal,
but the thing about being a human is we all have
this desire to have meaning. It's like the man
search for meaning. I think that's the title of
the book, you know, a really good book actually.
I think the bit you touched on right at the beginning is important there,
is this thing is to recognize that we're all
looking for the same thing. We're all looking
to be more at ease, to find peace, to find love in ourselves. Look for love outside,
it's really about finding love in ourselves. I
think it's the experience of loving is actually
more important than the experience of being loved.
We look for being loved. That is what gives life
meaning and to recognize we all want that.
It's not just that I want to be more at ease,
more at peace, more in touch with love myself, we
all do. And so instead of seeing you as somebody,
is this person going to help me be more in touch
with myself? It's like, oh, I hear somebody else
is looking for exactly the same thing. Everybody
on the planet is looking for the same thing.
And that opens up, I think, a lot of compassion, a lot of understanding,
and a whole new way of relating it gives meaning
to how we relate. Instead of, how can I get you
to give me what I need, is to turn that around.
How can I interact with you in such a way
that you feel more at ease, that you feel loved,
that you feel happier? What we tend to do is
because I'm wanting things for myself, we fall
into this stupid game, in order to get you
to give me what I want, I should be nasty to you.
I'll be mean to you. I'll manipulate you. I'll
control you. And then maybe you'll realize you
should be nice to me, then I'll be nice to you.
That's what happens in so many relationships.
It's like you piss me off, so I'm going to piss
you off. And then you'll realize here are your
ways to stop pissing me off. But if we break that
and just say, okay, you're wanting to be more at
ease, how can I make you feel at ease? How can I
interact with you in such a way that you feel more
loved, more appreciated? And if you come back to
me in the same way, relationships change. I see
the most fantastic changes happen, despite two
people saying, how can we give what the other
person wants to each other, rather than how can
I take the other person? That shift is profound.
Yeah, and so that begs the question to me,
where did the rift in humanity come? How did we
get to this place? You know, is it the breakdown

you know, why aren't we born with that sense

I think we are. I think we are born with it. I

We cannot go on with that mode of consciousness.

It's like this is the point we've reached in
